STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 20, 2025
Jennifer Shores
Livingston County DHHS
2300 E. Grand River Ave. Suite 1
Howell, MI, 48843-7577
RE: License#: CP470201250
Dear Ms. Shores:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 10/20/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12209 Orientation and training
(1) An agency shall ensure and document all the following:
(a) That each social service worker and each social service supervisor receives
not less than 16 hours of orientation after initial appointment and before
assumption of assigned duties.
One of four employees did not have orientation training on file.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
(4) An agency shall document placement specifications consistent with the
information contained in the reevaluation. The placement specifications must
include all the following:
(a) The age, number, SOGIE, race, ethnic background, and characteristics of
children preferred by the applicants.
Two of six foster home reevaluations did not include a preference for SOGIE in
the recommendation.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(4) Before completion of the written report required by subrule (6) of this rule, an
agency shall provide the foster parent with a verbal summary of the preliminary
findings at the conclusion of the evaluation.
One of one special evaluations did not have documentation that a verbal
summary was provided to the foster parent before writing the report.

CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must, include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a greater frequency is
medically indicated: (ii) A physical examination every 14 months.
One of six foster care files held a late medical exam, completed twenty-six
months after the previous exam.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents and the foster parents in
the development of service plans to enable the parent or parents and foster
parents to understand the plan for the child and the parents' and the foster
parent's role in assisting the agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give
a copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or parents
and foster parents. The agency must inform the parent or parents and foster
parent that the information in the parent-agency treatment plan and any other
information about the child and the child's family is confidential.
Five of six foster care files held Parent Agency Treatment Plans that did not have
foster parent signatures to indicate they provided input or received and reviewed
a copy of the report. The majority of the PATPs had a date the report was
provided to the parent or foster parent, but there were no subsequent attempts
documented to review the report or obtain a signature.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
(2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child, and the foster
parent, if applicable, in the child's placement at least once every month.
One of six foster care files was missing one monthly visit with the youth in the
foster home.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
• Sibling visitation- When visitation cannot occur the reason must be
documented in the file and service plan.
• Foster Parent Training- Training should be obtained from a variety of sources
and cover a variety of topics.
V. CONSULTATION
There was no consultation requested or required.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has not been required to submit any corrective action plans during
this period under review.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment dated 9/29/25 was reviewed and discussed.
As there was not a CAP required after the 1/23/25 Interim review, the agency did
not have any CAP progress to report on. The Chief Administrator reported the
agency continues to have high Key Performance Indicators in most areas.
However, parent & child visits was an area that needed improvement as it was at
69% compliance. The agency reported one unplanned removal of a child in a pre-
adoptive home. This was due to a death in the family which impacted the
caregiver's ability to meet the child's needs.
Financial Overview
Not applicable.
Staff Interviews
Two foster care staff were interviewed. Both staff had been with the agency for
over one year. One staff reported they had a great supervisor that was
knowledgeable, easy to talk to and able to balance when to be involved and when
to step back. The second staff reported their supervisor was knowledgeable, but
not always as helpful as they needed. Both staff reported multiple director
changes over the past few years had made things challenging at times. However,
staff have been able to work together and support one another. Both staff
expressed some concern about being required to return to the office three days a
week, as well as the change to the teaming model in the upcoming months. Both
staff reported they were just reassigned to a new supervisor, and a new Director
has joined their office. Both staff are hopeful the new leadership will make the
transitions smooth.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency continues to be located in the same building as the previous year. The
office building has sufficient space for staff to work, as well as visitation and
meeting space for clients. The agency has adequate secure storage space for files
and confidential information, as well as a cross shredder for CHRI.

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were three identified safety alerts.
Safety Alert 1: The DCWL analyst made several attempts to schedule a visit with
the licensed foster home. However, the foster parents did not schedule a visit.
Resolution: The agency initiated a special evaluation and completed a home visit
on 8/8/25 with the foster parents and children placed in the home. No safety
concerns were noted.
Safety Alert 2: The DCWL analyst made several attempts to schedule a visit with
the licensed foster home. However, the foster parents did not schedule a visit.
Resolution: The agency initiated a special evaluation and completed a home visit
on 8/19/25. The home did not have any children placed. No safety concerns were
noted.
Safety Alert 3: During a visit to the relative caregiver's home on 9/22/25, the DCWL
analyst observed smoke detectors were missing from the main and basement levels
of the home.
Resolution: The agency purchased smoke detectors. However, the relative
caregiver had already purchased and installed smoke detectors. The agency
observed the installed smoke detectors and provided photos to DCWL for
confirmation.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.

Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
